{{Year nav topic5|1626|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1626'''.
==Events== *[[December 27]] – [[Izaak Walton]] marries [[Rachel Floud]].
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Francis Bacon]] – ''The [[New Atlantis]]'' *[[Nicholas Breton]] – ''Fantastickes'' *[[Robert Fludd]] – ''Philosophia Sacra''<ref>[https://books.google.com/books/about/Roberti_Fludd_Philosophia_sacra_et_vere.html?id=BhEOAAAAQAAJ&redir_esc=y “Roberti Fludd ... ”Philosophia sacra et vere christiana seu meteorologia cosmica (Google eBook) Accessed 1 February 2013]</ref> *[[Marie de Gournay]] – ''[http://fr.wikisource.org/wiki/Grief_des_dames|Les Femmes et Grief des Dames]'' (The Ladies' Grievance) *[[Francisco de Quevedo]] – ''[[El Buscón]]''
===Drama=== *[[Pieter Corneliszoon Hooft]] – ''Baeto, oft oorsprong der Holanderen'' *[[John Fletcher (playwright)|John Fletcher]] and collaborators – ''[[The Fair Maid of the Inn]]'' *[[William Heminges]] – ''[[The Jews' Tragedy]]'' *[[Jean Mairet]] – ''La Sylvie'' *[[Philip Massinger]] – ''[[A New Way to Pay Old Debts]]'' *[[Thomas May]] – ''Cleopatra'' *[[Thomas Middleton]] – ''The Triumphs of Health and Prosperity''<ref>[http://thomasmiddleton.org/introscollected.php The Collected Works of Thomas Middleton. Accessed 1 February 2013]</ref> *[[Tirso de Molina]] – ''La Huerta de San Juan'' *[[James Shirley]] – ''[[The Maid's Revenge]];'' ''[[The Brothers (James Shirley)|The Brothers]]''
==Births== *January – [[Robert Howard (playwright)|Robert Howard]], English dramatist and politician (died [[1698 in literature|1698]]) *[[February 5]] – [[Marie de Rabutin-Chantal, marquise de Sévigné|Madame de Sévigné]], French letter writer (died [[1696 in literature|1696]]) *[[March 12]] – [[John Aubrey]], English antiquary and writer (died [[1697 in literature|1697]]) *[[June 3]] – [[Philippe Goibaud-Dubois]], French writer and translator (died [[1703 in literature|1703]]) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Elizabeth Egerton]], Countess of Bridgewater, English poet and dramatist (died [[1663 in literature|1663]]) **[[Alonso de Olmedo y Ormeño]], Spanish actor and dramatist (died [[1682 in literature|1682]])
==Deaths== *February – [[William Rowley]], English dramatist (born c. 1585) *[[February 28]] – [[Cyril Tourneur]], English dramatist (born [[1575 in literature|1575]]) *[[September 25]] **[[Lancelot Andrewes]], English scholar and bishop (born [[1555 in literature|1555]]) **[[Théophile de Viau]], French poet and dramatist (born [[1590 in literature|1590]]) *[[October 19]] – [[Béroalde de Verville]], French poet and novelist (born [[1556 in literature|1556]]) *[[December 8]] – Sir [[John Davies (poet)|John Davies]], English poet (born [[1569 in literature|1569]]) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Nicholas Breton]], English poet and novelist (born c. 1545) **[[Samuel Purchas]], English miscellanist and travel writer (born c. 1577)
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:1626 In Literature}} [[Category:1626 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 17th century in literature]]

{{Year nav topic5|1989|film|home video|television}} The year 1989 involved many significant films. ==Highest-grossing films== {{see also|List of 1989 box office number-one films in the United States}} The top ten films released in 1989 by worldwide gross are as follows: {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin:auto; margin:auto;" |+ Highest-grossing films of 1989{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?view2=worldwide&yr=1989&p=.htm|title=1989 Worldwide Grosses|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=May 1, 2014}} |- !Rank!!Title!!Studio!!Worldwide gross |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1. | ''[[Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade]]'' | [[Paramount Pictures]] / [[Lucasfilm]] | $474,171,806 |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2. | ''[[Batman (1989 film)|Batman]]'' | [[Warner Bros.]] / [[PolyGram Filmed Entertainment|PolyGram]] | $411,348,924 |- | style="text-align:center;"| 3. | ''[[Back to the Future Part II]]'' | [[Universal Pictures]] | $331,950,002 |- | style="text-align:center;"| 4. | ''[[Look Who's Talking]]'' | [[TriStar Pictures]] | $296,999,813 |- | style="text-align:center;"| 5. | ''[[Dead Poets Society]]'' | [[Touchstone Pictures]] | $235,860,116 |- | style="text-align:center;"| 6. | ''[[Lethal Weapon 2]]'' | Warner Bros. | $227,853,986 |- | style="text-align:center;"| 7. | ''[[Honey, I Shrunk the Kids]]'' | [[Walt Disney Pictures]] |$222,724,172 |- | style="text-align:center;"| 8. | ''[[Ghostbusters II]]'' | [[Columbia Pictures]] | $215,394,738 |- | style="text-align:center;"| 9. | ''[[The Little Mermaid (1989 film)|The Little Mermaid]]'' | Walt Disney Pictures | $184,155,863 |- | style="text-align:center;"| 10. | ''[[Born on the Fourth of July (film)|Born on the Fourth of July]]'' | Universal Pictures | $161,001,698 |- |} ==Events== {{Yearsinfilm}} * Actress [[Kim Basinger]] and her brother Mick purchase [[Braselton, Georgia]], for $20 million. (Basinger would lose the town to her partner in the deal, the pension fund of [[Chicago]]-based Ameritech Corp., in [[1993 in film|1993]] after being forced to file for bankruptcy when a California judge ordered her to pay $7.4 million for refusing to honor a verbal contract to star in the film ''[[Boxing Helena]]''.) * April 23 – ''[[Field of Dreams]]'', starring [[Kevin Costner]], [[James Earl Jones]], and [[Burt Lancaster]], is released. * May 24 – ''[[Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade]]'' is released. It is the third installment of the [[Indiana Jones (franchise)|Indiana Jones series]]. * June 13 – The [[James Bond (film series)|James Bond]] film ''[[Licence to Kill]]'' is released. Unknown to anyone at the time, it would be followed by years of legal wrangling over the future of the popular series. The next Bond film, ''[[GoldenEye]]'', is not released until 1995. * June 16 – ''[[Ghostbusters II]]'' is released. * June 23 ** ''[[Batman (1989 film)|Batman]]'' is released, going on to gross more than $410 million worldwide, and establishing the public and critical attention of director [[Tim Burton]]. ** ''[[Honey, I Shrunk the Kids]]'' is released and marks the directorial debut of visual effects supervisor [[Joe Johnston]], who later went on to direct ''[[The Rocketeer (film)|The Rocketeer]]'', ''[[Jumanji]]'', ''[[October Sky]]'', ''[[Jurassic Park III]]'', and ''[[Captain America: The First Avenger]]''. * July 7 – ''[[Lethal Weapon 2]]'' is released and becomes the highest-grossing film in the franchise. As well as the highest grossing R-rated film of the year at the domestic box office. * July 11 – Screen, stage, and Shakespearian legend [[Laurence Olivier]] died peacefully in his home in England, after appearing in his last filmed role as an old soldier in ''[[War Requiem (film)|War Requiem]]''. * August 2 – [[Ron Howard]]'s family comedy ''[[Parenthood (film)|Parenthood]]'', starring [[Steve Martin]], [[Tom Hulce]], and [[Rick Moranis]], is released. * September 28 – [[Sony]] announce its intention to buy [[Columbia Pictures]] and [[Tri-Star Pictures]]. The deal is completed in November for a total cost of nearly $5 billion. They appoint [[Peter Guber]] and [[Jon Peters]] as co-chairman, in a further deal that cost up to $1 billion, after settling a lawsuit with [[Warner Bros.]]. * November 7 - [[Andrew G. Vajna]] agrees to sell his stake in [[Carolco Pictures]] to his co-chairman and co-founder [[Mario Kassar]] for $106 million. * November 17 – ''[[The Little Mermaid (1989 film)|The Little Mermaid]]'' becomes a critical and commercial success and brings new life to [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Walt Disney Feature Animation]]. ''The Little Mermaid'' also reinvigorated public and critical interest in [[The Walt Disney Company]], which would become one of the most prestigious corporations of the 1990s. * November 22 – ''[[Back to the Future Part II]]'' is released. == Awards == {{Yearsinfilm}} {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:20px;"| Category/Organization !! colspan="2" style="width:250px;"| [[47th Golden Globe Awards]]

{{Year nav topic5|2004|film|home video|television}} {{Yearsinfilm}} The year '''2004 in film''' involved some significant events. Major releases of sequels took place. It included blockbuster films like ''[[Troy (film)|Troy]]'', ''[[Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film)|Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban]]'', ''[[The Bourne Supremacy (film)|The Bourne Supremacy]]'', ''[[Van Helsing (film)|Van Helsing]]'', ''[[The Passion of the Christ]]'', ''[[Resident Evil: Apocalypse]]'', ''[[Thunderbirds (2004 film)|Thunderbirds]]'', ''[[Meet the Fockers]]'', ''[[Harold and Kumar]]'', ''[[The Day After Tomorrow]]'', ''[[Anchorman (film)|Anchorman]]'', ''[[Saw (2004 film)|Saw]]'', ''[[Blade: Trinity]]'', ''[[Spider-Man 2]]'', ''[[Alien vs. Predator (film)|Alien vs. Predator]]'', ''[[The Incredibles]]'', ''[[Kill Bill#Volume 2|Kill Bill: Volume 2]]'', ''[[Fahrenheit 9/11]]'', ''[[I, Robot (film)|I, Robot]]'', ''[[Ocean's Twelve]]'' and ''[[Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed]]''. ==Highest-grossing films== {| class="wikitable" style="margin:auto; margin:auto;" |+ Highest-grossing films of 2004{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?view2=worldwide&yr=2004&p=.htm |title=2004 Worldwide Grosses |work=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=September 8, 2009}} |- ! Rank!! Title !! Distributor !! Worldwide gross |- ! style="text-align:center;"| 1 | ''[[Shrek 2]]'' | [[DreamWorks]] | $919,838,758 |- ! style="text-align:center;"| 2 | ''[[Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film)|Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban]]'' | [[Warner Bros.]] | $796,668,549 |- ! style="text-align:center;"| 3 | ''[[Spider-Man 2]]'' | [[Columbia Pictures|Columbia]] | $783,766,341 |- ! style="text-align:center;"| 4 | ''[[The Incredibles]]'' | [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Disney]] | $633,019,734 |- ! style="text-align:center;"| 5 | ''[[The Passion of the Christ]]'' | [[Newmarket Films|Newmarket]] | $611,899,420 |- ! style="text-align:center;"| 6 | ''[[The Day After Tomorrow]]'' | [[20th Century Fox]] | $544,272,402 |- ! style="text-align:center;"| 7 | ''[[Meet the Fockers]]'' | [[Universal Pictures|Universal]] / DreamWorks | $516,642,939 |- ! style="text-align:center;"| 8 | ''[[Troy (film)|Troy]]'' | Warner Bros. | $497,409,852 |- ! style="text-align:center;"| 9 | ''[[Shark Tale]]'' | DreamWorks | $367,275,019 |- ! style="text-align:center;"| 10 | ''[[Ocean's Twelve]]'' | Warner Bros. | $362,744,280 |} ''[[Shrek 2]]'' set a new record for total gross by an animated film making it the highest-grossing animated film of all time. The record was later surpassed by ''[[Toy Story 3]]'' in [[2010 in film|2010]]. On July 7, ''Spider-Man 2'' reached a $200 million domestic gross in a record time of eight days. On July 18, after 19 days in release, ''Spider-Man 2'' reached $300 million domestically in another record time. ''Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban'' has the highest international revenue of $546 million compared to ''Shrek 2'''s $478.6 million. ''[[The Passion of the Christ]]'', directed by [[Mel Gibson]], became the first [[blockbuster (entertainment)|blockbuster]] motion picture of 2004 and also the highest grossing [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|R-rated]] film domestically. ''Meet the Fockers'' beat 2003's ''[[Bruce Almighty]]'' record for the highest-grossing comedy film; both released by Universal. ==Events== {| cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4" border="0" |- bgcolor="#dae3e7" align="center" | '''Month''' || '''Day''' || '''Event''' |- valign="top" |rowspan="3" | January | 25 || [[Golden Globe Award]]s: Major winners include ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King]]'' and ''[[Lost in Translation (film)|Lost in Translation]]''. |- valign="top" | 26 || [[Golden Raspberry Award]] nominations announced, leading films are: * 9: ''[[Gigli]]'' * 8: ''[[Seabiscuit (film)|Seabiscuit]]'' * 6: ''[[Mystic River (film)|Mystic River]]'' |- valign="top" |rowspan="7"| February | 4 || [[9th Empire Awards]]: Major winners include ''[[Love Actually]]'' and ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King]]'' |- valign="top" | 15 || [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA Awards]]: Major winners include [[Scarlett Johansson]], Best Actress and [[Bill Murray]], Best Actor |- valign="top" | 22 || [[Screen Actors Guild#SAG Awards|Screen Actors Guild Awards]]: [[Charlize Theron]], The Actor for Best Female Actor, [[Johnny Depp]], The Actor for Best Male Actor, [[Tim Robbins]], The Actor for Best Male Supporting Actor, [[Renée Zellweger]], The Actor for Best Female Supporting Actor. |- valign="top" | 23 || ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King]]'' becomes the second film in history to gross more than $1 billion in worldwide box office receipts. |- valign="top" | 25 || ''[[The Passion of the Christ]]'', Mel Gibson's major motion picture about the last days of Jesus's life on Earth, opens huge in time for [[Lent]]. |- valign="top" | 28 || ''[[Gigli (film)|Gigli]]'' dominates the [[2003 Golden Raspberry Awards|Golden Raspberry Awards]], walking away with 6 awards, including Worst Picture, Worst Actress ([[Jennifer Lopez]]), Worst Actor ([[Ben Affleck]]), Worst Director ([[Martin Brest]]), Worst Screenplay (Brest) and worst on-screen couple (Lopez and Affleck). Worst supporting acting awards went to actress [[Demi Moore]] for ''[[Charlie's Angels: Full Throttle]]'' and actor [[Sylvester Stallone]] for ''[[Spy Kids 3-D: Game Over]]''. |- valign="top" | 29 || [[76th Academy Awards]]: ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King]]'' wins [[Academy Award for Best Picture|picture]] and [[Academy Award for Directing|director]] awards as well as nine others for a total of 11 [[Academy Awards]], a tie for the most ever won by a single film. |- valign="top" | May | 22 || ''[[Fahrenheit 9/11]]'', a controversial [[documentary film|documentary]] by [[Michael Moore]] wins the top prize, the ''Palme d'Or'', at the [[Cannes Film Festival]]. |- valign="top" | rowspan="2"| June | 5 || The [[2004 MTV Movie Awards]] were held at [[Sony Pictures Studios]] in Culver City, California and hosted by [[Lindsay Lohan]]. |- valign="top" | 27 || ''Fahrenheit 9/11'' breaks the record for highest opening-weekend earnings in the United States for a documentary, earning $23.9 million. And going on to earn over $119M in domestic box office earnings. |- valign="top" | October | 29 ||''[[Voices of Iraq]]'' released, the first "wikified" [[documentary film]] created by sending multiple DV cameras to participants. |- valign="top" |rowspan="3"| December | 13 || The [[Hollywood Foreign Press Association]] announced the nominees for the 2005 [[Golden Globes]] awards with comedy ''[[Sideways]]'' garnering seven nominations and actor [[Jamie Foxx]] with three for his work in both film and television. |- valign="top" | 21 || The [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] announces seven films are eligible for the [[Academy Award for Visual Effects]]: * ''[[The Aviator (2004 film)|The Aviator]]'' * ''[[The Day After Tomorrow]]'' * ''[[Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film)|Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban]]'' * ''[[I, Robot (film)|I, Robot]]'' * ''[[Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (film)|Lemony Snicket's a Series of Unfortunate Events]]'' * ''[[Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow]]'' * ''[[Spider-Man 2]]'' |- valign="top" | 28 || The [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] announces that 267 films released in 2004 are eligible for consideration of the [[Academy Award for Best Picture]]. |} ==Awards== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%;" |- ! rowspan=2 width=200| Category/Organization !! rowspan=2 width=250| [[10th Critics' Choice Awards]]

{{primary sources|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox company | name = Alaska Native Arts Foundation | logo = | type = [[Non-Profit]] | foundation = [[Anchorage]], [[Alaska]], [[United States|USA]] (2002) | location = Anchorage, Alaska | num_employees = 2 (2014) | key_people = Trina Landlord,
Executive Director
'''Board of Directors:'''
Perry Eaton, Chair
[[Alvin Eli Amason|Alvin Amason]], Susie Bevins-Ericsen, Da-ka-xeen Mehner, Barbara Overstreet, [[Mary Sattler]], Veronica Slajer, Cheryl Frasca and Georgia Blue | industry = [[Cultural arts]] | homepage = [http://www.alaskanativearts.org/ www.alaskanativearts.org] | }} The '''Alaska Native Arts Foundation''' (in operation 2002-2016){{Cite news|url=https://www.adn.com/culture/article/alaska-native-arts-foundation-close/2016/02/04/|title=Alaska Native Arts Foundation and gallery to close|date=2016-02-04|work=Alaska Dispatch News|access-date=2017-03-26|language=en-US}} was a [[non-profit]] organization formed to support the [[Alaska Native art]] community. Its mission was focused on economic development to create fairly-priced markets for Alaska Native art as well as to provide general awareness and public education of Alaska's indigenous cultures, and as a result offered programs to support Alaskan Native artists. Funded by a combination of government grants and private funding in the form of donations from Alaskan Native corporations{{Cite journal|last=Anchorage|first=Institute of Social and Economic Research, University of Alaska|last2=Sharman|first2=Haley,|last3=Ginny|first3=Fay,|last4=Joel|first4=Ainsworth,|last5=Jane|first5=Angvik,|last6=Alexandra|first6=Hill,|last7=Stephanie|first7=Martin,|date=2009-07-07|title=Benefits of Alaska Native Corporations and the SBA 8(a) Program to Alaska Natives and Alaska|url=https://scholarworks.alaska.edu/handle/11122/4324|language=en-US}}, the organization distributed grant money through project support programs to provide in-residence art programs, educational programs for rural schools, funding for museum demonstrations, art workshops, and exhibitions and documentation of native artists' work.{{Cite web|url=http://www.capitalcityweekly.com/stories/121008/ae_365871839.shtml|title=CapitalCityWeekly.com - Southeast Alaska's Online Newspaper|website=www.capitalcityweekly.com|access-date=2017-12-04}} == Curation of Native Works == The Native Arts Foundation gallery in Anchorage, which opened in 2006{{Cite web|url=http://www.sitnews.us/0216News/020716/020716_ak_native_arts.html|title=SitNews: Alaska Native Arts Foundation Will Close in 2016|last=SitNews|website=www.sitnews.us|access-date=2017-12-04}} presented and curated the works of Native artists, including visual art, spoken word, performance art and choreography, dance, fashion, and video{{Cite web|url=http://alaskanativestudies.blogspot.com/2013/09/memory-is-embodied-tanya-lukin.html|title=The Alaska Native Studies Blog: "Memory is Embodied:" Tanya Lukin-Linklater Interview|date=2013-09-27|website=The Alaska Native Studies Blog|access-date=2017-12-04}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.alaskapublic.org/2011/11/16/phenomenal-alaska-inspires-artist-gretchen-sagan/|title=Phenomenal Alaska Inspires Artist Gretchen Sagan|last=Foundation|first=Alaska Native Arts|work=Alaska Public Media|access-date=2017-12-04|language=en-US}}, as well as presenting works created during privately organized workshops and business training.{{Cite web|url=http://thecirifoundation.org/advanced-admin-panel/tcf-supports-revitalization-of-alaska-native-art/|title=The CIRI Foundation – TCF Supports Revitalization of Alaska Native Art|website=thecirifoundation.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-04}} Outside of Alaska, the foundation also promoted Alaskan Native art at events and festivals in [[Pittsburgh]], [[Washington D.C.]], [[Paris]], and [[Miami]]. In addition, the Foundation maintained extensive inventory of Native art and utilitarian handmade items of all sorts, based on the "subsistence" lifestyle of their makers: [[walrus ivory]] carvings, [[baleen]] etchings and baskets, [[whalebone]] sculpture, [[salmon]] and [[halibut]] skin baskets, fish skin crafts, caribou [[antler]] dolls dressed in traditional sealskin clothing, bronze sculpture and oil and acrylic paintings; and wearable art and accessories: jewelry, carved masks, traditional "[[ulu]]" knives, traditional [[Mukluk|mukluks]] made using natural material, summer parkas, beaded gowns using quills and moose hide, bolo ties, walrus whisker earrings, "[[scrimshaw]]" belt buckles, and silver, gold and copper jewelry.{{Cite web|url=http://www.alaska.org/detail/alaska-native-arts-foundation|title=Alaska Native Arts Foundation|website=Alaska.org|access-date=2017-12-04}} == Closure == The Foundation was dissolved in the spring of 2016 as the result of lost state funding and low markups on sold art. At the time of closure, the stock of the Foundation gallery was made available for private sale, and services were phased out to accommodate future marketing efforts. As operations ceased, the Foundation sought to distribute its intellectual property and valuable items to another organization. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.alaskanativearts.org}} [[Category:2002 establishments in Alaska]] [[Category:Alaska Native culture in Anchorage]] [[Category:Alaska Native organizations]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 2002]] [[Category:Native American arts organizations]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Anchorage, Alaska]] {{AnchorageAK-geo-stub}} {{NorthAm-native-stub}}

page.title: Albanian League of Writers and Artists

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2014}} The '''Albanian League of Writers and Artists''' (ALWA) ({{lang-sq|Lidhja e Shkrimtarëve dhe e Artistëve}}) is an organization of creators, located in [[Tirana]], [[Albania]],<ref>[http://www.writersclubinternational.com/worldwideliteraryorg.htm Worldwide Literary Organizations]</ref> which includes writers, composers, and artists and critics of the literary<ref>[http://letersia.zemrashqiptare.net/article/KritikeAnaliza/5574/ Homepage of Albanian Literature]</ref> and artistic values.<ref name="Elsie">{{cite book|author=Robert Elsie|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ox3Wx1Nl_2MC&lpg=PP1&dq=Robert%20elsie&as_brr=3&pg=PA162#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Albanian literature: a short history|publisher=I.B.Tauris| year= 2005| page=164|isbn=978-1845110314}}</ref>
== Foundation ==
ALWA was crystallized as a union of two organizations: "The Writers League", founded on October 7, 1945, and "The Artists League" founded in 1949. The First Congress was held in 1957, resulting in these two organizations merging in a single institution: ''The Albanian League of Writers and Artists''. [[Sejfulla Malëshova]] was appointed its leader and [[Fan S. Noli]] its honorary president.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} Among the most known creators were [[Lasgush Poradeci]], [[Nonda Bulka]], [[Skënder Luarasi]], [[Dhimitër Shuteriqi]], [[Sterjo Spasse]], etc. At the beginning there were by 70 members. Its statute describes its activities as: {{quotation|ALWA is a non-government organization, it was created by a group of Albanian writers and artists to propagate literary and artistic creativity of Albanian authors, to evaluate and re-evaluate the best works of the Albanian literature, music, painting and sculpture, traditional and contemporary values, and to encourage the creativity of young talents. ALWA protects and stimulates the best tendencies of the developments of literature and art to serve to the society and Albanian nation, under the best models of literary and artistic values of the civilized nations.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}}}
== Achievements ==
The League of Writers and Artists has played a role in the development of Albanian literature and art, especially for the selection, publication and propaganda of the works with Albanian nationality content. {{citation needed|date=January 2015}}
Among the membership of the League of Writers and Artists have been dissident-minded authors like [[Sejfulla Malëshova]], the first leader of this organization, like the writer Kasem Trebeshina, who was imprisoned for his creativity, like [[Pjetër Arbnori]] (also called ''Albanian Mandela''), who was re-convicted in prison for his literary anticommunist work, as the dissident [[Bilal Xhaferri]] who was expelled, exiled in communist gulags and forced to flee to the U.S., as Vilson Blloshmi who was shot and how many others who were persecuted in thousands ways. Some, like the poet [[Xhevahir Spahiu]], [[Dritëro Agolli]]<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.famouspoetryandpoets.com/biography/808/Drit%C3%ABro_Agolli |title=Dritëro Agolli, biography |access-date=2011-10-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402191445/http://www.famouspoetryandpoets.com/biography/808/Drit%C3%ABro_Agolli |archive-date=2012-04-02 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> or [[Ismail Kadare]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kirjasto.sci.fi/kadare.htm |title=Ismail Kadare |website=Books and Writers ''(kirjasto.sci.fi)'' |first=Petri |last=Liukkonen |publisher=[[Kuusankoski]] Public Library |location=Finland |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150113052232/http://www.kirjasto.sci.fi/kadare.htm |archivedate=13 January 2015 |dead-url=yes }}</ref> survived.
Some members of ALWA, part of communist censorship with their reviews have affected to ban dissident literature and art and have encouraged prosecution and persecution of dissident authors, but there were periods that they have supported and encouraged young talent. The writer [[Dritëro Agolli]], who has had longer the leader’ duty of this organization, in the 1980s followed a liberal politic to the support and promotion of the new talents.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}} With his initiative and recommendations have been allowed to follow the university studies and have been encouraged to create talents even from the most persecuted and anti-communist classes of Albanian society, like the poets Skënder Buçpapa, Mujo Buçpapa or prosers like Faruk Myrtaj, [[Shefki Hysa]] etc.
After 1990 ALWA contributed too much in the appreciation of art, literature and authors aforetime prohibited. However, during the post-communist period as well, with a very problematic democracy and highly politicized, the League of Writers and Artists is imposed an adulatory attitude toward the ruling party, the right one or the left one. The government tried to usurp ALWA and appointed leaders of Albanian creators taking advantage by the economical difficulties that writers, artists and organizations were experiencing.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}
Finally, after ALWA managed to escape from politics, it was found without economic support and on the verge of bankruptcy. In this difficult situation the state turned to it its back, got the building where its headquarters was but the writers and artists did not abandoned it. Most of them have realized that they must cooperate far from the policy of powers and parties. Writers and artists are those who keep alive ALWA in this difficult period full of crisis. Today, the ALWA has approximately 1300 members. Leading authorities are: National Congress, Chairmanship and Administrative Council. In the organizational structure operate: the section of literature, music, painting, sculpture, and the section of young talents.
== Publication ==
For more than 50 years, Albanian League of Writers and Artists has had its literary and artistic organs: the magazine "Literatura jonë" (English: Our Literature), followed by the monthly magazine "Nëntori" (English: November), later on the weekly "[[Drita (magazine)|Drita]]" (English: The light) (1961), the magazine "Les letters Albanaises" (1978) in French, "Bota Letrare" (English: Literary World), and "Revista Letrare" (English: Literary Magazine), as various publications until 1990.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} Currently the organization of Albanian writers and artists doesn’t publishes any organ due to lack of funds.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} In 2007, after 62 years of continuous activity, AlWA was displaced from their premises.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.shqiperia.com/lajme/lajm/nr/1255/Mbyllet-me-dryn-Lidhja-e-Shkrimtareve |trans-title=The Writers League premises are locked|language=Albanian|title=Mbyllet me dryn Lidhja e Shkrimtarëve |author=Koha Jonë|date= |publisher=Shqiperia.com|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref> However, ALWA currently continues its activities despite the economic burdens.
== Bibliography == * [[Academy of Sciences of Albania]], ''Encyclopedic Dictionary'', 2nd Edition, (2008), [[Tirana]], {{ISBN|978-99956-10-28-9}} * [[Robert Elsie]], ''Albanian literature: a short history'', I.B.Tauris, (2005), {{ISBN|978-1845110314}}.
==See also== *[[Albanian literature]] *[[Albanian culture]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Albanian League of Writers And Artists}} [[Category:1945 establishments in Albania]] [[Category:Albanian writers' organisations]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1945]] [[Category:Tirana]]

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
The '''Art dans Tout''' movement was a French art group which operated from 1896 to 1901.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Felix Aubert, Art dans Tout, and Art Nouveau Lace|jstor = 40662780|journal = Studies in the Decorative Arts|date = 2001-04-01|pages = 37–76|volume = 8|issue = 2|first = ROSSELLA|last = FROISSART-PEZONE|first2 = Richard|last2 = Wittman}}</ref> Originally called Les Cinq, because it had five founder members, artist and lace designer [[Félix Aubert]], sculptor and craftsman [[Alexandre Charpentier]], sculptor and medalist [[Jean Dampt]], sculptor and medalist Henry Nocq and architect [[Charles Plumet]], it later changed its name to Les Six when Nocq left the group in 1897, replaced by painter [[Étienne Moreau-Nélaton]] and architect and decorator [[Tony Selmersheim]]. In 1898, the group expanded further to become Art dans Tout when Carl-Albert Angst, a sculptor and student of Dampt,<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title = Art Nouveau: A Research Guide for Design Reform in France, Belgium, England, and the United States|last = Weisberg|first = Gabriel P.|publisher = Routledge|year = 1998|isbn = |location = |pages = 184, 238|last2 = Menon|first2 = Elizabeth K.}}</ref> Jules Desbois, a sculptor, [[Paul Follot]],<ref>{{Cite web|title = Ketterer Kunst, Art auctions, Book auctions Munich, Hamburg & Berlin|url = http://www.kettererkunst.com/bio/paul-follot-1877.php|website = www.kettererkunst.com|accessdate = 2016-01-05}}</ref> a furniture designer, Alphonse Hérold, a cabinetmaker, Antoine Jorrand, a painter and tapestry designer, [[Henri Sauvage]], an architect, and Louis Sorrel, an architect and collaborator of Aubert's, joined. The group dissolved in 1901 due to commercial necessity.<ref name="Arwas">{{Cite book|title = Art Nouveau: The French Aesthetic|last = Arwas|first = Victor|publisher = Papadakis Publisher|year = 2002|isbn = 9781901092370|location = |pages = 321, 616}}</ref>
The group's philosophy can be summed up in two concepts, that the form of a work of art should always fit its function and be artistic, and that the material the work is made from should always reflect the purpose of the object and the nature of the material.<ref name=":1" />
== Historical context ==
With the rise of machine production, the cost of producing object d'art and house decorations fell. In France, as around the rest of Europe, differing philosophies arose as to how to produce beautiful household objects and furniture for the masses, not just for the rich, following the philosophy of [[Eugène Viollet-le-Duc|Eugène-Émmanuel Viollet-le-Duc]]. Followers of [[Eugène Viollet-le-Duc|Viollet-le-Duc]] believed that banal, mediocre interiors had a negative effect on the development, morality and intellect of people who lived in them.<ref name=":2" /> Various attempts at collaborations between artists and industries that produced these items occurred.<ref name=":0" /> In France, these attempts had mostly ended in failure.<ref name=":0" /> Several of the artists in the group worked in a style that was part of the larger [[Art Nouveau]] style.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=L'ART DANS TOUT - Les arts décoratifs en France et l'utopie d'un Art nouveau|last=Froissart Pezone|first=Rossella|publisher=CNRS Éditions|year=2005|isbn=9782271062819|location=|pages=}}</ref> The group was part of a tentative but determined attempt to break down the barriers between art, industry and everyday life.<ref name=":2" />
Nocq in his role as art critic wrote an article on improvements in street design seen in England and Belgium, and encouraged France to follow their lead.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Décoration & Le Rationalisme Architecturaux a L'Exposition Universelle|last = Clausen|first = M. L.|publisher = Brill Archive|year = 1987|isbn = 9789004078796|location = |pages = 104}}</ref>
== Les Cinq == Les Cinq originally came together in Autumn 1896, meeting in Charpentier's workshop on Sunday afternoons.<ref name=":0" /> Their first exhibition was held from December 1896 - January 1897 at the Galerie des Artistes Modern.<ref name=":0" /> In their preface to the exhibition catalogue of the first exhibition, the group set forth their philosophy of bringing together the major arts (painting, sculpture and architecture) and the minor arts (ceramics, furniture and decorative objects), and to produce objects that served both functional and decorative purposes.<ref name=":0" /> They also exhibited a furnished boudoir for the Salon de la [[Société Nationale des Beaux-Arts]].<ref name=":0" /> In this room, Aubert designed the wall-hangings, curtains, carpet and fabric decorations, Charpentier the window-sash bolt and bottle-stoppers and Plumet, the dressing table, chair, shelf-unit, glass display case and the structure of the screens.<ref name=":0" />
== Les Six == In December 1897, the group enlarged to become Les Six. In their 1897-1898 exhibition, Aubert and Charpentier designed a bathroom with the decorator Eugène Simas, which fulfilled the group's ideals of bringing beauty to an object that served a functional purpose, and was also part of an industrial collaboration, with the Sarreguemines factory.
== Art dans Tout == The group expanded further in 1898 to include members that could not always attend the Sunday meetings.<ref name=":0" /> The group planned to construct and furnish an entire house for the 1900 International Exhibition in Paris, but could not accomplish this due to a lack of funding.<ref name=":0" /> An Aubert and Charpentier-designed bedroom (for Prince Alexandre de Chimay and his wife) was part of the group's 1899 exhibition at the Galerie des Artistes Modern.<ref name=":0" /> Members of the group collaborated with Léon Benoville and Édmond Socard in designing the interiors of other Parisian houses.<ref name=":0" /> Sorrel designed a pavilion for the International Exhibition of 1900 which Aubert decorated.<ref name=":0" />
== Post-group activities ==
Although the group disbanded in 1901 due to financial issues, and an inability to convince major furniture manufacturers to use their designs, several group members continued to collaborate, notably Plumet and Selmersheim.<ref name="Arwas"/><ref>{{Cite web|title = L'utopie de l'art pour tous {{!}} L'Histoire|url = http://www.histoire.presse.fr/actualite/infos/l-utopie-de-l-art-pour-tous-01-06-2005-6471|website = www.histoire.presse.fr|access-date = 2016-02-04}}</ref>
== See also == * [[William Morris]] * [[Arts and Crafts movement]] * [[John Ruskin]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Art movements]] [[Category:Art Nouveau]] [[Category:French art movements]]

{{Infobox song | name = Atlantis | cover = Donovan-Atlantis_(song).jpg | alt = | border = yes | type = single | artist = [[Donovan]] | album = [[Barabajagal]] | B-side = {{plainlist| * "I Love My Shirt" {{small|(UK)}} * "To Susan On The West Coast Waiting" {{small|(US)}}}} | released = {{plainlist| * November 1968 {{small|(UK)}} * March 1969 {{small|(US)}}}} | format = [[Vinyl record]] 7" | recorded = May 1968 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Folk rock]]{{cite web |url= https://www.thoughtco.com/what-is-folk-rock-music-2521910|title= What is Folk-Rock Music?|last= Fontenot|first= Robert|date= 29 October 2015|website= ThoughtCo.|publisher= [[About.com]]|access-date= 12 March 2017}} | length = 4:58 | label = | writer = Donovan Leitch | producer = Donovan, [[Gabriel Mekler]] | prev_title = [[Hurdy Gurdy Man]] | prev_year = 1968 | next_title = [[Barabajagal (single)|Barabajagal]] | next_year = 1969 }} '''"Atlantis"''' is a song written and recorded by [[Scotland|Scottish]] singer/songwriter [[Donovan]]. It was released as a [[single (music)|single]] in 1968 (see [[1968 in music]]) and became a worldwide success; becoming a No.1 hit in [[Switzerland]] in 1969 (see [[1969 in music]]),{{cite web|title=Chart History |work=Swisscharts |url=http://swisscharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=No+Angels+%26+Donovan&titel=Atlantis+%2F+When+The+Angels+Sing&cat=s |accessdate=2007-12-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060511030513/http://swisscharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=No+Angels+&+Donovan&titel=Atlantis+%2F+When+The+Angels+Sing&cat=s |archivedate=2006-05-11 |df= }} No.2 in [[Germany]] and [[South Africa]], No.12 in [[Canada]], and No.4 in [[Austria]]. In the [[United States]], where it served as the [[b-side]] to "To Susan on the West Coast, Waiting," it reached No.7, whilst in the singer's native country the single managed only a modest No.23 placing. In 2001, Donovan and German pop band [[No Angels]] re-recorded the track for the [[closing credits]] of the [[Walt Disney Feature Animation]] picture ''[[Atlantis: The Lost Empire]]'' (2001). Included on a [[wikt:concomitant|concomitant]] album for the German-speaking music market, it was once more released as a single and re-entered the top five in [[Austria]] and [[Germany]]. ==1968 version== ===Theme=== The introduction is a quiet monologue regarding the idea that [[Atlantis]] was a highly advanced [[antediluvian]] civilization, and that Atlantean colonists were the basis of the mythological gods of ancient times. Aware of their fate, the Atlanteans sent out ships to carry the preservation of their civilization, thereby spreading it across the world. Later on, the song conveys the message that the singer's true love may be in Atlantis. The overall theme is common for the 1960s: fanciful mythology as the symbol of the counterculture movement, with the hope that true love will be found if ever Atlantis can be reached. ===Possible Paul McCartney contribution=== {{undue weight|section|date=September 2017}} Many believe that the song "Atlantis" contains background vocals by [[Paul McCartney]]. Backing up that claim is Harry Castleman and Walter Podrazik's book, ''All Together Now: The First Complete Beatles Discography, 1961—1975'' (New York: Ballantine Books, 1976, p. 384), which states that McCartney not only provided the background vocals but also played the tambourine on the song. However, according to Donovan in a 2008 interview with Goldmine Magazine, McCartney did not sing the backing vocals.[http://www.goldminemag.com/article/donovan-the-sunshine-superman-part-ii Goldmine Magazine], October 10, 2008. The album's liner notes, which state that the song was recorded in Los Angeles in November 1968, do not list McCartney as a performer on the album. Also, the works of Beatles expert [[Mark Lewisohn]] do not support the statement. Neither ''The Complete Beatles Chronicles'' (New York: Harmony Books, 1992) nor ''The Beatles Day by Day: A Chronology 1962-1989'' (New York: Harmony Books, 1987 & 1990) mentions McCartney's participation on this song. According to Lewisohn's chronology, (Lewisohn, ''The Beatles Day by Day'', page 110) McCartney spent the month of November 1968 mostly at his farm in Scotland. ===Release and reception=== Contract disputes at the time caused a complicated series of different releases in the United Kingdom and United States. It was originally released in the UK as a single with "I Love My Shirt" as the [[A-side and B-side|B-side]]. In 1969 it was released in the US on the album ''[[Barabajagal]]''. The LP was not released in the UK, however, and "Atlantis" was next released in the US as the B-side to "To Susan on the West Coast Waiting". The song was not deemed likely to be a hit in the US because of its length and the fact that the first third of the song is spoken prose and therefore not "radio-friendly". It was for this reason that, despite its success in Europe, "Atlantis" was demoted to B-side status. However, the record company A&R executives were proved wrong when the popularity of "Atlantis" far surpassed that of its A-side. The song was quite successful, reaching #7 on the [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] charts, and the song itself became an anthem of the [[hippie]] movement. ===Chart history=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:220px;"|Chart (1968-69) !! Peak
position |- |Australia (''[[Go-Set]]'') | style="text-align:center;"|15 |- |[[Austrian Singles Chart]] | style="text-align:center;"|4 |- |align="left"|[[Dutch Top 40]] | style="text-align:center;"|1 |- |align="left"|[[Irish Singles Chart]] | style="text-align:center;"|13 |- |align="left"|[[German Singles Chart]] | style="text-align:center;"|2 |- |New Zealand (''Listener'')[http://www.flavourofnz.co.nz/index.php?qpageID=search%20listener&qartistid=542#n_view_location Flavour of New Zealand, 16 May 1969] | style="text-align:center;"|2 |- |Swiss Singles Chart | style="text-align:center;"|1 |- |align="left"|[[UK Singles Chart]] | style="text-align:center;"|23 |- |align="left"|U.S. [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] | style="text-align:center;"|7 |- |align="left"|Canada ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Top 100 | style="text-align:center;"|12 |- |align="left"|South African Chart | style="text-align:center;"|2 |} ==2001 version== {{Infobox song | name = Atlantis | cover = Noa-atlantis.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[No Angels]] | album = [[Elle'ments]] | released = November 19, 2001 | format = {{hlist|[[Music download|Download]]|[[CD maxi single]]}} | recorded = 2000 | studio = Park Studios,
([[Lake Starnberg|Tutzing]], [[Germany]]) | venue = | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]] | length = 4:14 | label = {{hlist||Cheyenne|[[Polydor]]|Zeitgeist}} | writer = Donovan Leitch | producer = [[Leslie Mándoki]] | prev_title = [[There Must Be an Angel (Playing with My Heart)|There Must Be an Angel]] | prev_year = 2001 | title = [[When the Angels Sing]] | title2 = Atlantis | next_title = [[Something about Us]] | next_year = 2002 }} ===Production and recording=== In the late 1990s, [[Walt Disney Feature Animation]] started production on ''[[Atlantis: The Lost Empire]]'', an [[animation|animated]] [[science fiction]]/[[action film]], based on the [[Atlantis]] saga. Interested in slipping his 1968 version into the [[Atlantis: The Lost Empire (soundtrack)|film soundtrack]], Donovan immediately opened negotiations with the studios; however Disney was barely interested in the song and plans eventually fell through. By [[2000 in film|2000]], Disney had committed [[Germany|German]] [[music producer|producer]] [[Leslie Mándoki]] to produce a concomitant album for the German-speaking music markets, entitled ''Stars Inspired by Atlantis''. After stumbling over the original song, Mándoki approached Donovan by phone, describing him his idea of a collaboration with German newcomers [[No Angels]], with whom Mándoki had previously worked on their debut ''[[Elle'ments]]'' (2001), and a few days later Donovan and the band met at the [[Lake Starnberg]] to start recording.{{cite web|first=Dirk|last=Peitz|title=Mit 'Atlantis' aus der Versenkung|work=Rhein Zeitung|url=http://rhein-zeitung.de/on/01/11/23/magazin/news/donovan.html|date=2001-11-23|accessdate=2007-12-23}} === Release and reception === "Atlantis" served as the band's fourth single along with "[[When the Angels Sing]]", a [[midtempo]] [[ballad (music)|ballad]] from their debut album ''[[Elle'ments]]'' (2001). [[CD single|Physical CD single]]s of the [[double-A side|double-A single]] were released on November 19, 2001 by Cheyenne Records. The [[maxi single]] includes the duet version, the Submarine Mix of "Atlantis" and three new remixes "When the Angels Sing". Upon its release, "When the Angels Sing"/"Atlantis" debuted at number five on the [[German Singles Chart]] in the week of December 3, 2001. It spent six weeks within the top ten and fell out of the chart in the 14th weeks, becoming the 79th highest-selling single of 2001 in Germany. In Austria, the double-A single debuted at number ten on the [[Ö3 Austria Top 40]]. It peaked at number five in its third week and spent four more weeks within the top ten, leaving the top 75 after 14 weeks. In Switzerland, "When the Angels Sing"/"Atlantis" entered the [[Swiss Hitparade]] at number 56 in the week of December 2. It reached its peak, number 16, in its second week, becoming the band's first single to miss the top ten. It fell out of the top 100 after twelve weeks on the chart. === Music video === The single's [[music video]] was directed by [[Hannes Rossacher]] for [[DoRo Productions]] and shot in [[Berlin, Germany]] in fall 2001. It shows Donovan and the band in a recording studio accented by underwater settings, backdrops, and scenes inspired by the animated movie. ===Track listings=== {{tracklist | headline = Maxi single{{cite web|title=When the Angels Sing / Atlantis|publisher=[[Discogs]]|url=https://www.discogs.com/de/No-Angels-Donovan-Atlantis/release/1848389|accessdate=2017-04-13}} | extra_column = Producer(s) | title1 = [[Atlantis (Donovan song)#2001 version|Atlantis]] | note1 = Radio Mix | length1 = 4:14 | title2 = When the Angels Sing | note2 = New Radio Mix | length2 = 3:47 | title3 = When the Angels Sing | note3 = Christmas Mix | length3 = 3:56 | title4 = When the Angels Sing | note4 = Special X-Mas Mix | length4 = 4:08 | title5 = Atlantis | note5 = Submarine Mix | length5 = 4:00 }} ===Credits and personnel=== Credits adapted from the liner notes of ''Elle'ments''. {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} *[[Nadja Benaissa]] – vocals *Laszlo Bencker – [[Keyboard instrument|keyboard]]s, [[bass guitar|bass]] *[[Lucy Diakovska]] – vocals *Pit Floss – additional engineering *Felix Knöchel – assistant engineer * George Kopecsni – [[acoustic guitar]] *[[Leslie Mándoki]] – [[music production|production]], [[drums]], [[percussion]] {{col-2}} *[[Sandy Mölling]] – vocals *[[Vanessa Petruo]] – vocals *Mike "Spike" Streefkerk – [[Audio mixing (recorded music)|mixing]] *[[Jessica Wahls]] – vocals *Peter Wölpe – guitar *Stefan Zeh – additional engineering {{col-end}} ===Charts=== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ====Weekly charts==== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !align="left"|Chart (2001) !align="left"|Peak
position |- {{singlechart|Austria|5|artist=No Angels & Donovan|song=Atlantis / When The Angels Sing|accessdate=2012-07-06|refname="aut"}} |- {{singlechart|Germany2|5|artist=No Angels & Donovan|song=Atlantis / When The Angels Sing|id=4962|accessdate=11 October 2018|refname="ger"}} |- {{singlechart|Switzerland|16|artist=No Angels & Donovan|song=Atlantis / When The Angels Sing|accessdate=2012-07-06|refname="swi2001"}} |} {{col-2}} ====Year-end charts==== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Chart (2002) ! Rank |- |Germany ([[GfK Entertainment Charts|Official German Charts]]){{cite web|url=https://www.offiziellecharts.de/charts/single-jahr/for-date-2002|title=Top 100 Singles-Jahrescharts (2002)|publisher=Offiziellecharts.de|accessdate=2015-11-22}} | style="text-align:center;"|79 |} {{col-end}} ===Certifications=== {{certification Table Top}} {{certification Table Entry|region=Austria|type=single|title=Atlantis|artist=No Angels|award=Gold|relyear=2001|autocat=yes|accessdate=2017-04-13}} {{certification Table Entry|region=Germany|type=single|title=When the Angels Sing|artist=No Angels|award=Gold|relyear=2001|autocat=yes|accessdate=2017-04-13}} {{certification Table Bottom|nosales=yes}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.atlantis-scout.de/atlantis_donovan.htm Mistakes in Donovan's Atlantis] * {{MetroLyrics song|donovan|atlantis}} {{Donovan}} {{No Angels singles}} [[Category:Atlantis in fiction]] [[Category:Songs about oceans and seas]] [[Category:Songs about places]] [[Category:1968 singles]] [[Category:1969 singles]] [[Category:2001 singles]] [[Category:Atlantis: The Lost Empire]] [[Category:Donovan songs]] [[Category:No Angels songs]] [[Category:Number-one singles in Switzerland]] [[Category:Songs written by Donovan]] [[Category:Disney songs]] [[Category:1968 songs]]

revision.comment: Reverted to revision 854953727 by [[Special:Contributions/Tmangray|Tmangray]] ([[User talk:Tmangray|talk]]): Rv, seems a bit pointless to mention that somewhere in London is in London six different ways. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{infobox UK place| |country = England |region = London |official_name = Bankside |london_borough = Southwark |constituency_westminster = [[Bermondsey and Old Southwark (UK Parliament constituency)|Bermondsey and Old Southwark]] |post_town = LONDON |postcode_area = SE |postcode_district = SE1 |dial_code = 020 |os_grid_reference = TQ319805 |coordinates = {{coord|51.5082|-0.1001|display=inline,title}} |static_image_name = St Paul's - Tate Modern.JPG |static_image_caption = Bankside including the [[Tate Modern]] }}
'''Bankside''' is a district of [[London]], England, and part of the [[London Borough of Southwark]]. Bankside is located on the southern bank of the [[River Thames]], {{convert|1.5|mi|km|1}} east of [[Charing Cross]], running from a little west of [[Blackfriars Bridge]] to just a short distance before [[London Bridge]] at St Mary Overie Dock to the east which marks its distinct status from that of 'the Borough' district of [[Southwark]]. It is part of a [[business improvement district]] known as '''Better Bankside'''.
==History== ===Toponymy=== The 'banke' was reclaimed by the [[Bishop of Winchester]] who owned the manor of the [[Liberty of the Clink|Clink]] of which this is part. There is a map plan in the [[Duchy of Lancaster]] archive showing 'the way to the banke'.<ref>'Old Southwark and its People' by William Rendle 1878</ref> The name is recorded in 1554 as ''the Banke syde'' and means 'street along the bank of the Thames'. It is formed from [[Middle English]] 'banke' and 'side'.<ref name="Mills">{{ cite book | surname=Mills | first=D. | title=Oxford Dictionary of London Place Names | year=2000 | publisher=Oxford}}</ref> In 1860 [[Southwark Street]] was created to connect the Blackfriars and London bridge crossings here and that can be regarded as the area's informal southern perimeter.
===Urban development=== Bankside is the riverside of the former liberties of the [[Liberty of the Clink|Clink]] and [[Liberty of Paris Garden|Paris Garden]]. In the Elizabethan period, because of its location outside the jurisdiction of the [[City of London]], the area of the Clink and Paris Garden were outside of the [[City of London]]'s authority and so became occupied by the bear baiting pits and playhouses, including the [[The Rose (theatre)|Rose]], the [[Hope Theatre]], the [[The Swan (theatre)|Swan]] and the [[Globe Theatre]] of which a replica was constructed in the late 1990s. The history of the area is traced in a study that traces the earliest known history of a particular building on Bankside until the present day.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/73956885|title=The house by the Thames : and the people who lived there|last=Gillian.|first=Tindall,|date=2007|publisher=Pimlico|isbn=1844130940|location=London|oclc=73956885}}</ref> It has experienced regeneration in recent decades, becoming a significant tourist destination, and forms a business improvement district. The skyline of Bankside is dominated by the former [[Bankside Power Station]], which now houses the [[Tate Modern]].
A major new development in the area is the Bankside 1/2/3 complex on Southwark Street. Together, these three building house about 5,000 employees. Bankside 1, also known as the Blue Fin Building, was built-for and partially-occupied-by [[IPC Media]], while Bankside 2 and 3 are occupied by [[The Omnicom Group Ltd]]. The architect for the buildings was [[Allies and Morrison]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.landsecuritieslondon.com/portfolio/Bankside-123 |title=Land Securities London Portfolio - Bankside 1/2/3, SE1 |publisher=[[Land Securities]] |accessdate=7 August 2013}}</ref>
==Governance== It is part of the Borough and Bankside Community Council which corresponds to the Southwark electoral wards of [[Cathedrals (ward)|Cathedrals]] and [[Chaucer (Southwark ward)|Chaucer]].<ref name="Councils">{{cite web|url=http://www.southwark.gov.uk/download/4663/community_councils_map |title=Where's your community council |author= |publisher=Southwark London Borough Council |date= |accessdate=4 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304034012/http://www.southwark.gov.uk/download/4663/community_councils_map |archivedate=4 March 2012 }}</ref> They are part of the [[Bermondsey and Old Southwark (UK Parliament constituency)|Bermondsey and Old Southwark]] Parliament constituency and the Member of Parliament is Labour's [[Neil Coyle]]. It is within the [[Lambeth and Southwark (London Assembly constituency)|Lambeth and Southwark]] London Assembly constituency and the [[London (European Parliament constituency)|London]] European Parliament constituency.
==Transport== Since 1754 the [[Blackfriars Bridge]] formed a connection to the north and in 1819 [[Southwark Bridge]] has connected the area into the City. In 2000 a direct pedestrian connection was opened between the Tate Modern and [[St Paul's Cathedral]] via the [[Millennium Bridge (London)|Millennium Bridge]], which also hosts two Cycle Hire stations <ref name="BorisBike">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.london-se1.co.uk/news/view/4729 |title=Bankside Mix tops the league on first day of Barclays Cycle Hire [2 August 2010] |publisher=London-se1.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-07-24}}</ref> [[Blackfriars station|Blackfriars]] station on the City side north bank of the river has been redeveloped as part of the [[Thameslink Programme]] and opened a Bankside entrance in 2012. [[London Bridge station|London Bridge]] and [[Southwark tube station|Southwark]] are the other stations closest to Bankside, located to the east and south of it respectively. It is served by bus routes 381 and RV1 which are [[Hydrogen vehicle|hydrogen powered]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.london-se1.co.uk/news/view/6197 |title=RV1 hydrogen bus fleet off the road due to the Olympics [21 July 2012] |publisher=London-se1.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-07-24}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Bankside Farmers]] - A group of five early American colonists originally resident in the Bankside district of London.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.london-se1.co.uk/areas/bankside.html Bankside page on London SE1 community website] * [http://www.betterbankside.co.uk Better Bankside - official Business Improvement District website] * [http://www.banksidemix.co.uk Bankside Mix - local promotion and tourism website]

{{Infobox film | name = Blue Gate Crossing | image = Blue Gate Crossing film.jpg | caption = ''Blue Gate Crossing'' DVD cover | director = [[Yee Chin-yen]] | writer = [[Yee Chin-yen]] | starring = [[Bolin Chen]]
[[Gwei Lun-mei]]
[[Liang Shu-hui]] | producer = [[Peggy Chiao]]
[[Hsu Hsiao-ming]] | distributor = Arc Light Films
Strand Releasing | budget = | released = 27 September 2002 (Taiwan) | runtime = 85 minutes | country = Taiwan | language = [[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]] | }} '''''Blue Gate Crossing''''' ({{zh|t=藍色大門|p=lánsè dà mén}}) is a 2002 [[Taiwan]]ese [[film]] by writer-director [[Yee Chin-yen]]. It was nominated for ''Best Asian Film'' at the [[23rd Hong Kong Film Awards]] held in 2004.{{zh icon}} [http://www.hkfaa.com/history/list_23.html 23rd Hong Kong Film Awards nomination list] Retrieved 2011-04-07 ==Cast== * [[Chen Bolin]] as Zhang Shihao * [[Gwei Lun-mei]] as Meng Kerou * Liang You Lin as Lin Yuezhen ===Cameo=== * [[Jay Shih]] as Pipi ==Reception== The film has been well-received critically. Dennis Lim, in a review for the ''Village Voice,'' observed the film's "meticulous framing and haunting use of repeated motifs" reflects the influence of [[Cinema of Taiwan|Taiwanese New Wave]] directors [[Hou Hsiao-hsien]] and [[Edward Yang]].[http://www.villagevoice.com/film/0347,lim2,48761,20.html Girl Who Likes Girl Who Likes Boy: Taipei Teens Work It Out] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016234106/http://www.villagevoice.com/film/0347%2Clim2%2C48761%2C20.html |date=October 16, 2007 }} 18 November 2003. Retrieved 2011-04-07. The ''Portland Mercury'' described the film as "a modern-day Chinese lesbo twist on the old ''[[Cyrano de Bergerac (play)|Cyrano]]'' story" that "treads new territory in the teen coming of age drama realm," praising Yee's "haiku-like directorial lyricism." [http://www.portlandmercury.com/portland/Content?oid=29970&category=22133 Seventh Annual PLGFF] Retrieved 2011-04-07. == Events == * 2002：[[Cannes Film Festival]] "[[Directors' Fortnight]]" * 2002：[[Toronto International Film Festival]] * 2002：[[Tokyo International Film Festival]] * 2002：[[Busan International Film Festival]] * 2002：[[Seattle International Film Festival]] Competition * 2002：[[Vancouver International Film Festival|Vancouver Film Festival]] * 2003：[[Bangkok International Film Festival|Bankok Film Festival]] * 2003：[[Adelaide Film Festival]] * 2003：[[International Istanbul Film Festival|Istanbul International Film Festival]] * 2003：[[San Francisco International LGBT Film Festival]] * 2003：Dublin LGBT Film Festival * 2003：[[Milwaukee LGBT Film & Video Festival]] * 2002：[[Asia-Pacific Film Festival|Asia Pacific Film Festival]] * 2004：Belgium Holebi LGBT film festival ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.time.com/time/asia/magazine/article/0,13673,501030804-471206,00.html "A Taipei Love Triangle"], ''TIME'' * {{IMDb title|0333764|Blue Gate Crossing}} [[Category:2002 films]] [[Category:Lesbian-related films]] [[Category:Taiwanese films]] [[Category:Mandarin-language films]] [[Category:Taiwanese LGBT-related films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:LGBT-related drama films]] {{LGBT-drama-film-stub}} {{Taiwan-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{About|the former London theatre|the unrelated modern Cockpit Theatre in Marylebone|Cockpit Theatre (Marylebone)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Use British English|date=May 2015}} [[File:Inigo jones theatre.jpg|thumb|These plans, originally thought to be drawn by [[Inigo Jones]] , but now attributed to his protege John Webb, may be for the '''Cockpit Theatre'''. The drawings were originally believed to be the Blackfriars theatre.]] The '''Cockpit''' was a [[theatre]] in [[London]], operating from 1616 to around 1665. It was the first theatre to be located near [[Drury Lane]]. After damage in 1617, it was named '''The Phoenix'''.
==History== [[File:London map showing Shakespearean theatres.png|thumb|The Cockpit Theatre is labelled to the far left of this London street map. [[:File:London map showing Shakespearean theatres.png|Enlarge]]]] The original building was an actual cockpit; that is, a staging area for [[cockfight]]s. Most likely a round building with a peaked roof, about {{convert|40|ft|m|0}} in diameter, it was erected under Henry VIII, c. 1530-32, as part of a gaming complex. Records indicate a major restoration in 1581-82 and renovations in 1589-90, 1602-3, and 1608-9 (the latter under the supervision of John Best, "cockmaster" to [[Henry Frederick, Prince of Wales]], King [[James I of England|James I's]] eldest son and heir).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Astington|first=John H.|date=Autumn 1982|title="The Whitehall Cockpit: The Building and the Theater"|jstor=43447083|journal=English Literary Renaissance|volume=12| issue = 3|pages=307}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=The Theatres of Inigo Jones and John Webb|last=Orrell|first=John|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1985|isbn=9780521255462|location=Cambridge|pages=90}}</ref><ref>Gurr and Orrell, p. 142.</ref>
In August 1616, [[Christopher Beeston]] acquired the lease to the building and converted it to an indoor playhouse.<ref>Wickham, p. 117.</ref> In March 1617, gangs of apprentices attempted to destroy the playhouse, probably out of anger that their favorite plays had been removed from the Red Bull outdoor amphitheater, which charged only one penny for admission, to this more expensive (six-penny) venue''.'' Beeston's rapid restoration of the playhouse after this riot may be why it was sometimes called the Phoenix.<ref name=":0" /> Like earlier theatres, such as [[The Theatre]] in [[Shoreditch]] and [[Globe Theatre|The Globe]] in [[Southwark]], the location was just outside the jurisdiction of the [[City of London]]. Beeston expanded the original small building; the construction work prompted complaints by neighbors, which left traces in the legal records of the time.<ref>Gurr and Orrell, pp. 142-3.</ref> The resulting theatre was, by one estimate, {{convert|52|ft|m|0}} by {{convert|37|ft|m|0}}, "noticeably smaller than the [[Blackfriars Theatre|Blackfriars]]."<ref name=":0">Gurr, ''Shakespearean Stage,'' pp. 24-25.</ref>
The architect commissioned for the renovation is not known for a certainty, but circumstantial evidence points to [[Inigo Jones]]. Two sheets drawn by Jones and showing the interior and exterior design of ''some'' theatre have survived; [[John Orrell]] makes the case that the theatre is the Cockpit, while allowing that he cannot produce conclusive evidence to that end.<ref>''Shakespeare Survey 30,'' p. 157.</ref> (In 1629, Inigo Jones would design another "Cockpit" theatre, a private one within [[Palace of Whitehall|Whitehall]] called the [[Cockpit-in-Court]] or Royal Cockpit.)
Beeston intended the Cockpit to serve as an indoor complement to the [[Red Bull Theatre|Red Bull]], the outdoor theatre then home to his acting troupe, [[Queen Anne's Men]]. A winter venue was needed to compete with the [[Blackfriars Theatre]] in the possession of their rival troupe, the [[King's Men (playing company)|King's Men]]. After a rocky start, the company proved successful in their new locale. Wickham attributes the success more to the theatre's location and comfort and to the flair of its manager, Beeston, than to the quality of its performers.<ref>Wickham, p. 118.</ref>
Beeston would oversee several different troupes in the Cockpit before his death in 1639. [[Queen Anne's Men]] were there from 1617 to 1619; when that company dissolved upon the death of [[Anne of Denmark]] in 1619, their place was taken by [[Prince Charles's Men]] from 1619 to 1622. [[Lady Elizabeth's Men]] were there from 1622 to 1624, and perhaps for sporadic periods as early as 1619 (the two companies, Prince Charles's and Lady Elizabeth's, had combined for a time ca. 1615). [[Queen Henrietta's Men]] had a long run at the Cockpit, from 1625 to 1636. The last troupe to occupy the Cockpit in Beeston's lifetime was one of his own creation, the King and Queen's Young Company, colloquially known as [[Beeston's Boys]] — the last assembly of [[boy player|boy actors]] in the period. They would continue in the theatre under the management of his son [[William Beeston|William]].<ref>Thomson. p. 225; Harbage, p. 356.</ref>
William Beeston was forced out of the theatre when his choice of plays met with the disapproval of the Court. He was replaced by [[William Davenant]] in 1639. All theatres were [[London theatre closure 1642|closed by Parliament]] in 1642, under the [[Commonwealth of England|Commonwealth]]. The Cockpit was used as a schoolroom, but plays continued to be shown illegally. It was raided by [[Puritan]] soldiers during a performance in 1649 and the players were imprisoned. In 1651 William Beeston paid £200 for repairs to the theatre, in the hope that he would be able to start performances there again — though the hope proved illusory.<ref>Gurr and Orrell, p. 146.</ref> In the last years of the [[English Interregnum]], under the common conceit that music was not acting, Davenant was permitted to present two licensed operas in the Cockpit: ''The Cruelty of the Spaniards in Peru'' in 1658 and ''Sir Francis Drake'' in 1659.<ref>Thomson, p. 225.</ref>
The theatres were permitted to reopen after the [[English Restoration]] in 1660, when [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] granted [[Letters Patent]] to two companies to perform "legitimate drama" in London: the [[Duke's Company]], led by Davenant, and the [[King's Company]], led by [[Thomas Killigrew]]. Both companies briefly made use of the earlier generation of theatres including the Cockpit and the [[Salisbury Court Theatre]], but quickly moved to newer and more fashionable venues — Davenant in 1661 to a theatre in [[Lincoln's Inn Fields]] that was once [[Lisle's Tennis Court]], and Killigrew in 1660 to [[Gibbon's Tennis Court]] in Vere Street. The Cockpit was also used in this era by the companies of [[John Rhodes (17th century)|John Rhodes]] and [[George Jolly]]. [[Samuel Pepys]] wrote in his diary of several visits to the theatre between 1660 and 1663.
In 1663, Killigrew's King's Company opened the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]] nearby. The Cockpit was unable to compete with this relatively grand new theatre and was further hamstrung since it was shut out of the monopoly on "legitimate drama" granted to the two [[patent theatre|patent companies]]. There is no record of any play being mounted at the Cockpit after 1665; the eventual fate of the structure is unknown.
The Phoenix was located in the middle of the area bounded today by Drury Lane, Great Queen Street, Great Wild Street, and Kemble Street. The entrance to the theatre was in Cockpit Alley, which ran from Drury Lane to Great Wild Street; the present-day Martlett Court is off Drury Lane roughly opposite where the entrance to Cockpit Alley was.<ref>Berry, 623.</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist|2}}
== References == * Herbert Berry, "The Phoenix". In Glynne Wickham, Herbert Berry, and William Ingram, editors, ''English Professional Theatre, 1530–1660''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000. 623–637. * [[Andrew John Gurr|Gurr, Andrew]], with [[John Orrell]] (1989). ''Rebuilding Shakespeare's Globe.'' New York, Routledge. * Gurr, Andrew (1992). ''The Shakespearean Stage.'' Third edition, Cambridge, Cambridge University Press. * Harbage, Alfred, et al. (1989). ''The Annals of English Drama 975–1700.'' London: Routledge. * [[John Orrell|Orrell, John]] (1977). "Inigo Jones at The Cockpit", Muir, Kenneth ed. ''Shakespeare Survey'' 30. Page references are to the 2002 paperback edition. *Thomson, Peter (1995). "Cockpit Theatre", Banham, Martin ''The Cambridge Guide to Theatre''. Cambridge University Press, p. 225. * Wickham, Glynne (1972). ''Early English Stages 1300 to 1660: Volume Two 1576 to 1660, Part II''. London: Routledge.
==External links== *[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.asp?compid=45148 'Drury Lane Theatre'], Old and New London: Volume 3 (1878), pp. 218–27. *[http://www.pepysdiary.com/p/1238.php The Diary of Samuel Pepys] *[http://ise.uvic.ca/Library/SLT/stage/cockpit.html Inigo Jones designs a stage] *''[http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/22397 Shakespearean Playhouses]'', by [[Joseph Quincy Adams, Jr.]] from [[Project Gutenberg]]
==See also== *''[[A Maidenhead Well Lost]]''
